locationInformation.description: Mumbai, formerly known as Bombay, is the capital city of the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is the most populous city in India and the fourth most populous city in the world. Mumbai is a major financial, commercial, and entertainment hub, and is known for its bustling streets, diverse culture, and iconic landmarks such as the Gateway of India and the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel.
locationInformation.history: Mumbai has a rich history that dates back to the ancient times. The city was originally a group of seven islands inhabited by fishing communities. It was later ruled by various dynasties and empires, including the Maurya Empire, the Chalukyas, the Rashtrakutas, and the Delhi Sultanate. In the 16th century, the Portuguese gained control of the islands and established a trading post. The islands were later ceded to the British East India Company, and Mumbai became an important trading port under British rule. After India gained independence in 1947, Mumbai emerged as the financial and commercial capital of the country.
locationInformation.weather: Mumbai has a tropical monsoon climate, with hot and humid summers (Mar–Jun), heavy rainfall during the monsoon season (Jun–Sep), and mild and dry winters (Nov–Feb). The city receives an average annual rainfall of about 2,200 millimeters (86 inches), with the majority of the rainfall occurring between June and September. The temperature in Mumbai ranges from 25°C (77°F) to 35°C (95°F) during the summer months and from 15°C (59°F) to 25°C (77°F) during the winter months.

risks.name: Hurricane Sandy
risks.description: Hurricane Sandy was the deadliest and most destructive hurricane of the 2012 Atlantic hurricane season. Inflicting nearly $70 billion in damage, it was the second-costliest hurricane on record in the United States until surpassed by Hurricanes Harvey and Maria in 2017. The eighteenth named storm, tenth hurricane, and second major hurricane of the year, Sandy was a Category 3 storm at its peak intensity when it made landfall in Cuba. While it was a Category 2 hurricane off the coast of the Northeastern United States, the storm became the largest Atlantic hurricane on record (as measured by diameter, with winds spanning 1,100 miles).

risks.name: Blizzard Jonas
risks.description: Blizzard Jonas was a historic winter storm that affected the Northeastern United States, including New York, in January 2016. It brought heavy snowfall, strong winds, and blizzard conditions, resulting in significant disruptions to transportation, power outages, and closures of schools and businesses. The storm dumped over 2 feet of snow in some areas and caused widespread travel delays and cancellations. Blizzard Jonas was one of the largest snowstorms to hit New York City in recent history.

risks.name: Extreme Heat Wave
risks.description: In August 2018, New York City experienced an extreme heat wave that brought record-breaking temperatures and dangerous heat indices. The heat wave lasted for several days, with temperatures soaring above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and heat indices exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit. The extreme heat posed health risks to residents, especially the elderly, children, and individuals with pre-existing medical conditions. The city implemented heat emergency plans, opened cooling centers, and issued heat advisories to help residents stay safe during the heat wave.

risks.name: Remnants of Hurricane Ida
risks.description: The remnants of Hurricane Ida brought heavy rain and severe flooding to New York City on September 1, 2021. The storm caused record-breaking rainfall, leading to flash floods, power outages, and transportation disruptions. The flooding overwhelmed the city's infrastructure, submerging streets, homes, and subway stations. The severe weather event highlighted the vulnerability of New York City to extreme weather events and the need for climate resilience measures.

risks.name: Nor'easter Storm
risks.description: The Nor'easter Storm in January 2022 brought heavy snowfall, strong winds, and blizzard conditions to New York City. The storm resulted in significant disruptions to transportation, power outages, and closures of schools and businesses. It dumped several inches of snow in some areas and caused travel delays and cancellations. The Nor'easter Storm was one of the major snowstorms to hit New York City in recent years.

mitigations.name: New York City Stormwater Resiliency Plan
mitigations.description: The New York City Stormwater Resiliency Plan is a comprehensive strategy to address the city's vulnerability to flooding and storm surges. The plan includes measures such as green infrastructure, coastal protection, and stormwater management to reduce the impact of extreme weather events and enhance the city's resilience to climate change. By investing in infrastructure upgrades and flood protection measures, the city aims to mitigate the risks of flooding and improve the overall resilience of its communities.

mitigations.name: PlaNYC: Getting Sustainability Done
mitigations.description: PlaNYC: Getting Sustainability Done is a comprehensive sustainability plan for New York City. It was launched in 2007 with the goal of making the city more sustainable and resilient to the challenges of climate change. The plan focuses on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, improving air quality, conserving water resources, enhancing green spaces, and promoting sustainable transportation and energy efficiency. PlaNYC includes a wide range of initiatives and policies to achieve these goals, such as expanding public transportation, retrofitting buildings for energy efficiency, and increasing the use of renewable energy sources. By implementing PlaNYC, New York City aims to create a greener, healthier, and more sustainable future for its residents.

mitigations.name: The Financial District and Seaport Climate Resilience Master Plan
NYC CoolRoofs
mitigations.description: NYC CoolRoofs is a program that aims to reduce energy consumption and mitigate the urban heat island effect in New York City by coating rooftops with reflective materials. By applying cool roof coatings, buildings can reflect more sunlight and absorb less heat, resulting in lower energy costs for cooling and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. The program offers incentives and technical assistance to building owners and managers to encourage the adoption of cool roofs. Additionally, NYC CoolRoofs helps create green jobs and improve the overall sustainability and resilience of the city's built environment.
